title: 110_hr3383
content: The Act titled "Defense Contracting Ethics Oversight Act of 2007" requires ethics compliance by Department of Defense contractors. The "Defense Contracting Ethics Oversight Act of 2007" mandates that Department of Defense contractors must have an internal ethics compliance program in place for the award of covered contracts. This program includes a code of ethics and internal controls to detect and address improper conduct. The "Defense Contracting Ethics Oversight Act of 2007" requires contractors to have mechanisms in place for periodic performance reviews, internal reporting of improper conduct, audits, disciplinary actions, and reporting to Government officials. The Inspector General of the Department of Defense must report suspected improper conduct among contractor personnel, including corruption involving Government officials, within 30 days of discovery. Mechanisms are required for full cooperation with investigators, recurring training for personnel on ethics compliance, and oversight by personnel with substantial authority within the contractor. The deadline for a contractor to have an ethics compliance program in place for a covered contract is 30 days after the contract award. The Department's contracting officer may seek assistance from the Office of the Inspector General of the Department of Defense to determine program existence. Contractors failing to report suspected improper conduct may face suspension or debarment under the regulations. The ethics compliance program for covered contracts can be suspended or debarred by the Secretary of Defense if the contractor fails to report suspected improper conduct. A covered contract is defined as any contract awarded to a Department of Defense contractor with total government contracts exceeding $5,000,000 in the previous year. SEC. 3. REPORT TO CONGRESS ON PERSONAL FINANCIAL CONFLICTS OF INTEREST. The Administrator for Federal Procurement Policy, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Government Ethics, must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of this Act's enactment. The report will describe current laws and regulations on personal financial interests for Federal and non-Federal employees, along with recommendations for extending these restrictions to employees of covered Government contractors providing advice to Federal agencies. The term "covered Government contractor" refers to entities awarded contracts by Federal agencies where individuals provide advice on acquisition planning, closely resembling Federal employees' responsibilities. The term "Federal employee" refers to employees of Federal agencies or federally funded research and development centers. The term "Federal agency" includes executive, legislative, and judicial branches of the Government, excluding specific entities. A "federally funded research and development center" is identified as such. A federally funded research and development center identified by the National Science Foundation in accordance with the Federal Acquisition Regulation.
